Award.AwardTitle: Constraining Tephra Aggregation Efficiency with Laboratory Experiments and Numerical Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Leah Courtland has been awarded an NSF Earth Science Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at Georgia Institute of Technology. This study will use a combination of laboratory experiments and numerical modeling to better constrain the rate of tephra (volcanic ash) aggregation in the uppermost regions of volcanic plumes. Laboratory experiments will utilize an ice nucleation chamber to parameterize the rate of tephra aggregation under a variety of relative humidities and applied electric field strengths. The main goal is to improve our understanding of the response of tephra in the atmosphere to the relative humidity conditions prevalent in volcanic plumes and the presence of an electric field within these plumes. The result of experiments will be a parameterization of the expected change in particle size distribution for varying plume conditions (humidity, temperature, electrical field). If successful, this will allow tephra dispersion models to use near-real- time meteorological data to better forecast particle residence time in the atmosphere. Research results will help to constrain tephra hazard models used in crisis response scenarios. Improvement in these models should ultimately lead to increased aviation safety and more effective hazard mitigation strategies for far-field tephra impacts on the ground.

Tephra fallout is the most far reaching hazard of volcanic eruptions, capable of causing roof collapse, polluting water supplies, damaging critical facilities, and threatening the health of people and livestock. The 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallaj√∂kull in Iceland spewed ash into the atmosphere for days, effectively shutting down most of European air space, affecting hundreds of thousands of travelers, and costing the aviation industry billions of dollars. The global nature and high economic consequence of this event expose an urgent need for accurate forecasts of the distribution of tephra in the atmosphere and on the ground. While the study of the transport and sedimentation of volcanic ash over the last forty years has greatly increased our understanding of these processes and enabled the development of numerical models to simulate tephra dispersion, the injection of large volumes of fine (<63 um) ash into the atmosphere is not yet captured in a meaningful way by the current generation of tephra models. The discrepancy between model calculations and the true distribution of tephra reflects the failure of the majority of models to account for natural processes that rapidly remove the fine ash fraction of volcanic ejecta from the atmosphere as constituent pieces of larger aggregates. To facilitate understanding of ash aggregation while fostering model literacy and quantitative skills building among university students, a series of educational modules will be designed and implemented via the Vhub.org web platform. VHub.org is an online resource for volcano modeling and education. The numerical parameterization of ash aggregation to result from this work will ultimately be installed on Vhub.org as well, in order facilitate use of the model by the larger scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Triboelectrification of Volcanic Ash

 

Volcanic ash is the most far reaching hazard of volcanic eruptions, capable of causing roof collapse, polluting water supplies, damaging critical facilities, and threatening the health of people and livestock. The study of the transport and sedimentation of volcanic ash has greatly increased our understanding of these processes. However, in the case of an overabundance of fine ash, there is a discrepancy between scientific model calculations and the true distribution of tephra due to a lack of understanding of natural processes that that rapidly remove the fine ash fraction of volcanic ejecta from the atmosphere as constituent pieces of larger aggregates. A lack of understanding of the physical mechanisms of aggregation at work in volcanic plumes and clouds highlights the need for scientists to better constrain the parameters that govern aggregation processes.

 

The current research utilized laboratory experiments to measure the magnitude of charge build-up on ash particles over a range of temperature-pressure-relative humidity conditions, thereby providing insight into the charge transfer process thought to be the dominant force holding together electrostatic aggregates.

 

Particles in all experiments acquired positive and negative charges with maximum amplitudes that ranged between 10-13 and 10-11 C. A clear decrease in acquired charge was seen with increasing temperature, suggesting more efficient charge retension at colder temperatures. Below 50% relative humidity, the charge on grains increases with increasing relative humidity, however beyond 50% RH, the ability of particles to attain charge decreases and electrification is all but arrested near 90% RH. The charge on particles increases with increasing pressure, however the charge density on real particles rarely attains values close to the theoretical maximum.

 

These insights into the charging mechanisms of volcanic particles will hep researchers worldwide to understand the process(es) of triboelectrification and fine ash aggregation.

 

Over the course of this project, a number of electrical apparatus were designed and built, including a voltage amplifier capable of detecting charges on the order of 10-9 C. This incredibly sophisticated apparatus is likely to have an impact in physical engineering as well as across the earth and atmospheric sciences.

 

 

Volcanic Projectile Trajectories and Impact Energies:

Particles ejected in successive volcanic bursts will impact/interact with particles of the next burst. This significantly alters both the trajectories and the impact energies of these particles, in some cases resulting in volcanic blocks traveling farther than expected from the predictions of ejection models that do not take collisions into account.

 

Before volcanic particles are even ejected, they are highly likely to experience high-speed collisions both with other particles of the same burst as well as with the conduit walls. For a bubble burst event occurring at 1.5 m depth within the conduit, over 70% of particles experience some form of collision before exiting the vent. These collisions result in a unique velocity spread of particles that may enable researchers to back out the initial conduit conditions if provided with high speed video of an eruption.

 

Insights into the trajectories and impact energies of volcanic projectiles gained through the computational modeling conducted as part of this project will help to constrain mitigation efforts worldwide. The ability to take a video dataset of particles being ejected from a vent and back out the conditions within the conduit could provide insight into eruption mechanisms for Strombolian style eruptions around the world.

 

Model Literacy

The educational component of this project will have a significant impact on undergraduate students of all disciplines. One of the fundamental goals of the educational modules is to introduce students to the ideas of quantitative and model literacy, increasingly important topics in a world where more and more questions are being probed and decisions made based on the results of numerical models. By employing these models in undergraduate courses primarily designed for non-majors, a wide audience of students will be familiarized with the philosophies and practicalities of scientific modeling.

 

Summary

This project will enable researchers to more accurately parameterize the hazards posed by volcanic eruptions, both due to volcanic ash fallout and due to the emplacement of ballistic projectiles 10 cm in diameter or greater. This will enable volcanic hazards assessments to be conducted before said eruptions occur, allowing mitigation measures to be be put into affect both before and during volcanic crises. This includes mitigation efforts targeted at both ground infrastructure as well as regarding our ability to track volcanic ash for aircraft safety. Therefore this work ultimately contributes to safeguarding human populations around the world.

 

The educational component contributes to model literacy, which is important in any nation where citizens have access to information garnered via modeling and are expected to make informed decisions based on this model output, whether that be volcanic hazards, land use policies, energy policies, etc.
